content.description: This thing is 5.9 in the guidebook but I found it a bit harder than the neighbor. I don't think it is quite PG13 but certainly PG. Definitely worth getting on! Good climbing that feels a little more sporty after the tougher start
content.protection: Now equipped with anchors, standard rack

content.description: Steep face climbing that stays dry in the rain.  A thin section just before mid way is the crux but a few off balance moves up higher keep the pump going.  A bit loose in spots.
content.protection: Chain link bolts.  Needs an upgrade.
content.location: Located at the far left edge of the Broom ledge.  The left most of 2 bolted face routes.  Skip the right hand route.  Its a choss pile but Witches Broom is a worthwhile venture.

climbs.name: The White House Project
climbs.fa: Closed Project - Equipped by Brian Jones and Jesse Heineman

content.description:
Steep climbing on perfect stone... wild exposure/positioning!

 As with The Truman Show Project, I (and many others) worked very closely with the land managers for a number of years to get access to bolt this particular route.  The Obed bolting moratorium is still in place; no other new routes are allowed at this time.

If you have any questions about new route potential at North Clear, please contact me at bjones@acs.ac.
content.location: This climb is about 50 feet left (upstream) of the existing trad route Triple X.  The line starts off of the ~40 foot ledge.  Some adventuring is necessary to reach the ledge!

content.description: This is one of the few warm ups at North Clear.  Look for 4 bolts in the gray rock.
content.location: Located between Saddam Hussein and Southern Exposure.

content.description: Climb up the wavy, huecoed rock to a stance below a roof. Pull the roof and continue on fun plates on easier terrain to the top of the cliff. There is no anchor, but there is a pretty good tree. As of April 2020, equipped with a shiny anchor thanks to ETCC. You will need a 70m rope to get down.
content.protection: Standard rack. Now equipped with an anchor at the top
content.location: This route is to the south of the Great Roof.

content.description: Fun overhanging blocky climbing through the slot leads to an arete. Cruise through the airness to the top.
content.location: Towards Squeeze Ledge in the Dihedrals, before Apple Pie crack and Ship's Ahoy

content.description:
Excellent sequential and flow-y climbing. The route stops at the first set of anchors under the big roof, going out the roof is a closed project. 

 Another classic on the shale wall.
content.location: First bolted route on the shale wall, right of the Rumors of War area

content.description:
Located between Saddam Hussein and 441, this route, named for my dad, Truman, begins approximately 15 feet to the right of a couple of cedar trees on the left side of the Shale Wall.  Climbs the slightly overhanging, bouldery and powerful face for the first 40 feet or so, pulls two distinct bulges onto a vertical section, and then launches into the monstrous roof with big moves between mostly good holds. 

  This route is a product of teamwork.  In the Obed guidebook, Stan Wallace quotes Craig Stannard as saying, “We’re all standing on the shoulders of others.”  I have personally been working with the appropriate land managers on getting access to bolt this route for about five years now, but the process began long before that.  Thanks to Rick Bost and John Nowell for allowing me to stand on their shoulders! 

The Obed bolting moratorium is still in effect; no other new routes are allowed at this time.  If you have any questions concerning new route potential at North Clear, please contact me at bjones@acs.ac   

  -Brian
content.protection: 18 bolts to chain anchors at the lip.  May need an 80 meter rope to lower to the ground!

content.description: climb a technical face below a small roof crack, pull over the buldge and follow the jugs to the top.
content.location: just to the right of Vulture Culture

content.description: Climbs the face between Sane Addiction and No Sandwich Shall Be Left Untouched. There is a cold shut and a chain at the top, which can be used to rappel into the Sun Ledge.
content.protection: Standard rack, up through #3 BD Camalot

climbs.name: Tempest
climbs.fa: FA Brad Carter, Glenn Ritter  FFA Jerry Roberts

content.description: Starts on the far right end of the Rasputin ledge on the chossy bolted arete.  The arete is super loose but the upper headwall makes up for it.  Crank hard moves out the roof to gain entry to the steep corner.  Crank hard moves up the corner.  Sustained climbing.
content.location: Starts on the far right end of the Rasputin ledge on the chossy bolted arete.

content.description:
This route starts out with some dirty climbing, and has 2 dangerous loose blocks.  But the upper 50 ft may be the funnest 5.10 climbing you'll ever do, with several heel hooks and numerous big moves between huge holds on aesthetic rock.  Don't pull on the huge pancake rock right of the first bolt(easier to avoid than it looks), or the flake up and right of the last bolt.

 This route is either climbable from the ground, or by climbing one of the 5.easy approaches and building an anchor on the ledge.  If climbing from the ground, consider bringing a couple pieces to protect the dirty 5.6 direct start and then extend the first bolt.
content.protection: A couple optional pieces of gear, 6 or 7 bolts, and open anchors.
content.location: On Sun wall, the next bolted line right of Youth in Asia.

content.description: Slab start, a few techy moves off the ledge then either stay right of the bolt line for harder (11c) climbing with big moves or stay left on the arete for more balancy 11a climbing.
content.location: Right of Robbers Roost. Left of Rasputin Ledge

content.description:
Obvious crack to the right of puff the magic dragon. Even though this thing looks wide don't skimp on the smaller protection! A really fun, physical climb. Move through the crux midroute to the overhung perfect handjam crack for the last 15 feet or so of the route. 

 Stays dry when most other cracks are wet!

 Now equipped with anchors.
content.location: To the right of puff the magic dragon - if you hit another bolted (mixed line) you've gone too far.

climbs.name: Stone Temple Pilots aka (Rumors of War)
climbs.fa: FFA Steve Goins, bolted extension David Frazier

content.description:
Originally done by Steve Goins as a ridiculously pumpy gear climb this amazing route was later retro bolted.  Super steep and unrelenting.  No hard moves really but quite the pump.  A most inspiring line. 

  A somewhat loose 40 foot section starts things off but at the ledge rock quality improves.  Fun crack moves, jugs, and a few crimps get you to a rest.  A big move takes you to the juggy roof.  The upper headwall is steep and pumpy. 

   The climbing isn't over at the shuts.  Move left at the anchors for more steep juggy moves.  This allows you to climb all the way to the very top of the cliff.  You could mantle the lip even.  A long pitch.  Done this way it's perhaps 5.12 c/d.
content.protection: 16 bolts.  A few extra long below the flat roofs is key.     As of 12/25/2012 the bolt in the roof is missing a hanger.  The anchors need replacing as well.
content.location: Located a bit further right from the obvious Rasputin roofs locate the grey rock below an obvious right leaning left facing corner below massive roofs.

content.description: The climb starts with a few fun crack moves up to a huge ledge. The climb continues on large flakes up and right. The movement is really interesting and varied. Once the last bolt is clipped, keep climbing right even though the anchors are straight above you. Once you're even with the shuts, move back left to clip. Be careful here, having a long reach comes in really handy.
content.location: First bolted line left of "Frankenstine"

content.description: This amazing climb captured the imagination of Knoxville climbers for a long time before most of them had the skills to get on it.  A ridiculously overhanging pitch.  Robinson and Goins demonstrated to the Knoxville climbing community what hard trad was all about when they put this route up.
content.protection: Bring a full rack.  Stoppers up to #3 camalot
content.location: Located just left of Hang On to Your Ego.  Climbs overhanging wall to base of 10' roof to severely overhanging crack.

content.description: Little roof to begin, a long move in the middle, and a fun roof at the top. Lots of spiders up there.
content.protection: Four bolts and standard rack to open shuts.
content.location: Starts around 15 feet right of the large dihedral with No Sandwich Shall Be Left Untouched. First bolt is around 12 feet up.

content.description: "Obvious fat chimney.  This is also the start to Horizontal Skins, a 5.11 multi-pitch trad traverse for those seeking big adventure."
content.location: North Clear Creek.

content.description: Start on the smooth face and after the second bolt trend right. Look for the perfect hand sized hueco  for your left hand to keep moving. Move through the fun and gymnastic overhung area until just below the short roof. Pull the lip (crux) for good views and 5.9 climbing to the shuts!
content.protection: 13 bolts and cold shuts at the top
content.location: On a proud arete, This route is located a little after alpine dihedral but just before going up to the squeeze ledge. Shares start with Land Ho (5.12b)

content.description: Overhanging wide crack with a roof at the top. A little dirty at the bottom. Suprisingly featured and good rock. Easier than it looks. Mostly stemming in the lower and upper part and chimneying in the middle. One of the best moderate trad routes at North Clear in my opinion.
content.location: The farthest left route on the sun wall. Left of "The real poison ivy".

content.description: Big, big roof climbing on big holds.  A little bit intimidating.  The face is difficult too.  Crank this one off and you're ready for the Stephen King Library.
content.location: The middle line of the 3 bolted roof climbs on the Broom ledge.

content.description: Despite the chossy ledge midway and silly name I feel this route is a classic.  Above the 1/3 height ledge the rock changes to some of the most clean and textured stone I've ever seen.  The position near the top is fantastic.  AND the climb is nearly always dry, even in a downpour like most of the routes here.
content.protection: 16/18 (anchors) draws.  Cold Shuts for anchors.  If you're top roping make sure to use your own draws to save the wear on the shuts.  70 meter rope gets you down just fine.
content.location: On the far right edge of the Rasputin ledge but just before the massively overhung "Bee Wall."  Start in left facing corner.  Climb to ledge and belay or runner prudently and keep pullin'.

content.description: The crux is probably the move off the ground, which is protected with a bolt.
content.protection: One bolt, then cams and tri-cams from very small up through #3 BD Camalot
content.location: This route is on the Sun Wall, it climbs the arete left of No Sandqich Shall Be Left Untouched.

content.description: Start on the blocks, work up to a ledge with a small roof. Work up to the left-facing dihedral and move on up to the anchors.
content.location: This is the middle of the three sport routes to the left of the really wet, mossy section of the wall just north of the Broom Wall and Rasputin Ledge.

content.description: A fun corner which starts as a left facing dihedral and finishes in a right facing dihedral
content.location: Right of the serpent and left of the sport routes on Sun Ledge

content.description: Slab start to ledge. Pull onto the face, through some easy stuff then through a few techy moves below the buldge. Pull the buldge at the top and scramble to anchors.
content.location: left most route of the three on this face. Left of Rasputin ledge..

climbs.name: Rasputin D. Scaliwag
climbs.fa: FA Kelly Brown  FFA James Litz?

content.description: Super Classic roof climbing.  KB worked on this for a while and shoulder injuries kept him from the FFA.  I'm not sure about Litz doing the FFA but I've got a good hunch... If anyone knows let me know.
content.location: The left most climb on the broom ledge.

content.description: Start off the right hand side of the shale slope and leap to the starting hold (use the belayer bolt and have your belayer unclip it when you are at the third bolt). Rowdy...
An interesting and steep sport climb.  The upper headwall is very exposed and has some cool rests.  A spicy runout to the chains keeps things interesting.
content.location: Located not to far right of the giant "Bee" wall and left of the Chocolate wall.  May need to stick clip the first bolt.

content.description: This climb has a lot of the character of its neighbor youth in asia. Really fun juggy climbing that gets real pumpy with good protection in horizontals.
content.protection: I'd recommend a set of nuts and standard rack. Now equipped with an anchor

content.description: Not terribly classic but a great challenge.  The start is just crappy  you can't avoid it but, the upper section of this climb is on really great rock with some cool roof moves.  Good gear and bolted anchors.   Previously unreported.  Led free on preplaced gear in 2002 with Brady Robinson belaying.
content.protection: #0 -#2 camalot.  Maybe it should be retrobolted.  Might actually see some traffic.
content.location: Locate the obvious bolted arete.  This is chossy but grin and bear it cause the roofs are worth it.  At the top of the arete move right and crank out the horizontal roof crack.

content.description: Climb up through jug after jug. So fun.
content.location: Just right of Haulin and Ballin. The cold shuts are only one inch apart and not inspiring.

climbs.name: No Sandwich Shall Be Left Untouched

content.description: Climbs the corner of the large right-facing dihedral on the Sun Ledge. A lot funner than it looks.

Step off the boulder at the base and climb jugs (a few of which are loose, beware) to a rest at bolt 2, then push through a 4 or 5 move boulder problem on decent crimps and slopers, going right to a jug. A strenuous clip at 3 leads to high left feet and jugs to the top.
content.location: First route seen at North Clear, after the downhill part of the trail leading in look left and you can’t miss it. The start is on a landing 30 feet left of the trail leading to Arachnophobia.

content.description:
The Magnificent 7 climbs the prominent ships prow arete directly above Witches Broom. It is arguably the most classic arete climb at the Obed, and perhaps in all of Tennessee in my biased opinion. The stone is legit flawless and the position is super out there. You'll definitely be checking your knot up there.

 The crux is at the very top and employs a divine sequence of moves that makes you wonder if it was intelligently designed. It is not a quick tick and requires some advanced sport climbing rope techniques. However, It is worth the effort.

 The full pitch requires you to climb techy thin face, burly roof and crack moves, and finish with delicate and balancey arete climbing. It'll test you.
content.location:
Climb witches broom but at the 2nd to last bolt step left into a dihedral and climb easier ground to the base of the roof crack. Climb the roof crack to a two bolt belay. The start of the crack is often wet but the worst of the wet holds can be avoided if you're careful.

 You basically have 3 options to prevent rope drag. All 3 methods require more than your average sport climbing effort: 1. Use super long draws on the last few bolts of WB and in the roof. 2.Clip in to the 2 bolt anchor above roof crack and pull the rope through the draws of WB. Use the anchor bolts on the 2nd pitch. (clip anchor long. use a locker or two opposite/opposed biners) Make sure YOU"RE ON BELAY (!!) Continue up the arete rope drag free. (recommended) 3. Use double ropes.

  A 70 meter rope is necessary to get down from the upper anchor. But if you want to clean your gear off WB I recommend re-threading the rope thru the anchor at the base of the arete and cleaning in 2 pitches. Again,  not convenient but worth it. You could TR the full line to clean too.

content.description: This climb is located further down stream from the big roofs at North Clear.  Its the most obvious and pure crack line at the Obed.  You can't miss the soaring overhanging crack.  A very demanding pitch of climbing and highly unusual for the Obed.
content.location: Located just upstream from the obvious "point" at Clear Creak.  A straight in splitter crack.

content.description: Actually a super fun route - it has a bit of everything. The line protects well and is now equipped with anchors. Follow the right facing dihedral at the bottom and when in doubt move right through the roof.
content.protection: Equipped with anchors at the top
content.location: To the right of hang onto your ego and left of the chimney

content.description:
Put by Sites and Martin over the course of several trips this is surely the longest route in Tennessee.  Its a traverse but so what.  These guys thought outside the box and put up a great voyage through some extremely challenging terrain.  Thin face, wide crack, pumping footless climbing.  This climb will reward those seeking adventure with some real good memories. 

  Has probably never seen a one day ascent.  Named for a snake skin found over 100' up a cliff in overhanging terrain.
content.location: Basically you locate Hang on to your ego and climb the adjacent chimmney system, start traversing right for about 11 pitches...You basically traverse across the crack that splits the face from roof/headwall for most of N. Clear to the Bee Wall. Once you get to the end of the bee wall you follow a weakness to the top of the cliff.

content.description: Short, slopey, and bouldery. Powerful moves coming out of the cave with a hard sloper crux between bolts 2 and 3. Helps to have draws hung. A great sport climb for boulderers. Will clean up nicely with more traffic.
content.location: To the right of the Alpine Dihedral area in its own little cave. There is a large, open, sandy area at the base of the climb.

content.description: This route is sustained with about a 10-15 degree overhang and pretty large holds the whole way.
content.location: This route is on the Sun Wall between Conservative Guillotine and Nocturnal Animals.

content.description: Arguably one of the best 5.12 climbs at the Obed. Perfect rock. Sustained climbing. Great Pro. Crux at the very end. In an area of sport routes this climb is a fantastic testpiece for those looking for a little bit more excitement and challenge. Robinson scored a gem from the locals and fortunately inspired a few to put up a few trad routes of their own.
content.protection: If going for the onsight don't bother reading.  If you want some gear beta here it is.  The crack in the begining takes large to medium wires.  2-3 should do fine.  Next up is some medium size TCU's.  At the first real overhang place Purple camalot.  Crank the hard move.  Traverse right.  Place Green camalot.  Clip bolt.  Crank crux.  Get stood up and place blue metolius.  I won't say where...  Run it to the chains.
content.location: The first truly impressive wall you encounter as you walk the cliff line.  Set away from the trail a bit locate the obvious right slanting crack on the orange overhanging wall.  Lower from bolts

content.description: The companion climb next to Green Arrow but not quite as dapper.
content.location: Climb the corner located to the right of the white and green wall, next to Green Arrow.

content.description: A steep and commiting crux makes for one of the best (and only) trad routes at the grade.
content.location: Located just around the corner from Liposuction on a beautiful green wall.

content.description: Start in a shallow dihedral about 200 meters right of the approach pitch of Sun Ledge. Tricky protection but fun climbing.
content.protection: Now has anchors thanks to ETCC

content.description: A small crack system leads through or arround a small roof then up on a short face climb to a tree ledge
content.location: just to the right of a waterfall, just past the sun wall to the right.

content.description: This Route starts on a ledge that is a few hundred feet from the south clear descent trail. Climb a beautiful white face with technical crimps, lie backs, and a few well deserved jugs. Has recently been rebolted. Very fun movement with the only downfall being that the route is short. If you have medium gear, the belayer can be anchored in a horizontal below the first bolt because the belayer is right next to a big drop from the ledge.

"On the right side of the alcove, find the path of lease resistance working up and right, skirting the roofs." 

  Often wet.
content.location: North Clear Creek.

content.description:
Just right of the huge Rasputin Roofs is an obvious 2"-3" crack.  Scramble up the easy 5th class to the base of the crack and belay or continue climbing.  Crank the hard entry move (5.10ish) and climb the surprisingly easy crack to the roof.  Traverse across the giant horizontal and clip the first bolt.   

  Either crimp down or throw for the huge jug out and left.  Control the swing and set up to pull the lip.  Once over climb an easier crack and belay.  There should be bolts but the anchor may need a little love.  Extremely exposed.  A great little adventure.
content.protection: A full set of cams up to #4 camalot.  A few quickdraws.  A few long runners.
content.location: This route is located among the massive overhangs of North Clear Creek.  This route is probably dry every day of the year.  Only after a sudden warming trend and when the rock "sweats" would the route be wet.  Rappel/lower off the route.

content.description: Goes up black lichen and white streaks, horizontals and hand jams. Mostly straight up, diagonals left to weakness in roof. Crux is the leaning dihedral at the top.
content.protection: Standard Rack, shares open shuts with Smiley Face.
content.location: Starts in the broken corner with some brush, around 15 feet right of Smiley Face.

Climb Saddam Hussein or another route until you can move right to the base of a left facing corner and belay.  Traverse right above exposed drop to VERY exposed arete.  Climb to top of Bee Wall and belay.

content.description:
"Start on the arete just right of the alcove.  Avoid the roofs by working right around them." 

  Spotter encouraged at start of route, pro here is spotty.
content.protection: Standard rack, no anchors.  Extra on the finger-size gear.
content.location: Right of Dude with a Tude.

content.description: We always knew this route would be bad ass and it took the dynamic duo of KB and the Dew man to pull it off.  A very adventuresome climb through intimidating terrain.  I doubt this thing gets done once a year if that.  Only .12a this climb looks worse than it is but get ready cause you just might get humbled.
content.location: Locate the obvious Black Hole.  Climb up to and through it.  Climb out big roof belay at the awesome ledge.  Crank the crux second pitch.

content.description: "Climb the prow to the top of the buttress.  Often wet."
content.location: North Clear Creek.

content.description: 70m required. A great climb. Starts with a fingery boulder problem followed by easy climbing on sandy rock. Once you pull onto the left side of the arete enjoy the fun techy and sustained climbing with a Crux on crimps to the chains. Stays in the shade most of the day.
content.location: To the right of alpine dihedral

content.description: Climb up the face to a slightly over-hung area until reaching the roof. mantle up on to the top of the roof to a super sharp hold. Get a good foot and clip the bolts.
content.location: On the first wall you come to about 40 ft from Artificail Light.

content.description: "Perhaps the consciousness one needs to find to send. First done on gear." Great technical face climbing like its two neighbors to the left. Cool roof sequence and spaced out permadraws gets you to the lip.
content.protection: Only two older permadraws on the roof, then to the chains.
content.location: Rasputin ledge at North Clear. In between Scalded Dog and The Tempest.

content.description:
This line is a little confusing at first only because the first ledge at approximately 40' has a double bolt anchor. If you only want to do the lower section this is fine, but I would not recommend doing this route in two pitches. The 5.8+ crux is right off this ledge and a fall here so close to the anchor would be not so good. 

  Start by climbing the left facing corner to  an awkward bulge to the previously mentioned ledge. Take rest and pull the bulge above the ledge with a handcrack. Continue through a couple more 5.8 moves in a very nice and well protected hand crack. Traverse left near the top to find double bolt anchors at a spacious ledge. 

  Dixie Cragger's Atlas notes an alternate finish up and right, but I saw nothing that looked like it would go at 5.8 or less to the right; however it looked like an easy 4th class to the top continuing to the left past the belay ledge. 

  This is a great climb with challenging crux that is a little exposed and very worthy of your attention.
content.protection: A bolt just below the crux at the ledge and a bolt above the crux. both seemed useless as there is better protection nearby and probably added in the 90's. Otherwise a standard rack of nuts, tricams, and cams up to #4 camalot. Plenty of runners.
content.location: Two ropes to reach the ground or walk off.   The climb is easy to find by following the guidebook. It starts in a shady corner with a large hemlock

content.description: This route is not the typical Obed experience.  Start on some good hold and make your way up facey moves on crimps.  Eventually, you will make it to a big ledge to rest.  Clip the bolt and get ready to do some slab moves to past a bulge.  Scampering with then lead you to the anchors.
content.protection: multiple Bolts, Anchor was a old carabiner and quicklink.
content.location: 20 ft to the right of Alpine Dihedral.  To the right of bad press.

content.description:
This mega line is the only route on the intimidating Bee Wall.  Fun jug hauling gets you to a thin section on the face.  If you go left here it's around .11b, go right and its solid .12.  The choice is yours.  Rest up on the ledge then crank layback and crack moves to one more thin move to the anchor.   

  The route continues up the super steep headwall and tiered roofs.  The rest of the climb is .11d or so.  This is a killer adventuresome route that deserves more traffic.  The first "pitch" or half of the route seemed about .12b to me although the guide gives it 12d.
content.protection: 16 draws for the full pitch.  70m rope (tie a knot!) required.  However, if you do this as a single pitch you might consider clipping into the mid point anchor and pulling your rope through the draws.  Rope drag up high would be terrible.  Either way I'd put a double long on the anchor if you keep going out the roofs.  Use lots of long (shoulder length) runners especially for the 2nd pitch.
content.location: Dead center of the Bee wall.  Starts in a short right facing corner next to an old cedar tree.

content.description: Lots of rainy day climbing.
